questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplobacillus. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Class B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system
  • ➤ Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system
  • ➤ Inference:
  • ➤ Inference:

  • ➤ CTP A: 5-6
  • ➤ CTP A:
  • ➤ CTP B: 7-9
  • ➤ CTP B:
  • ➤ CTP C: 10-15
  • ➤ CTP C:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Rajasthan is diagnosed with mixed malaria infection – P. falciparum + P. vivax. Treatment regimen on Day 2 would be: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

options.label: B
options.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

options.label: C
options.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

options.label: D
options.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.correct_answer: A. Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In mixed malaria infections involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, primaquine 2.5 mg is used on Day 2 along with artesunate to effectively treat both species.

questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prevotella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

questions.text: What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? ( INICET MAY 2023) Disrupted cell membrane Induces inflammation Swelling of the cell Can be seen physiologically
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FEATURES OF NECROSIS
  • ➤ FEATURES OF NECROSIS

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

questions.text: A person who chronically consumes alcohol and indulged in binge drinking ten days’ back was brought to the hospital. At the presentation, he was unconscious. His Non-Contrast CT scan was normal. His blood glucose came out to be 49 mg/dL. What treatment should be initiated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. I.m thiamine followed by dextrose
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) I.m thiamine followed by dextrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with alcohol dependence presenting with hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the precipitation of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.
  • • Asherman Syndrome
  • • These are intra-uterine adhesions They usually follow a history of sharp curettage Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility
  • • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility
  • • Diagnosis –
  • • TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium
  • • HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)
  • • Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy
  • • Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tubal ligation : Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.
  • • Option A. Tubal ligation
  • • Option C. Endocervical polyp : In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.
  • • Option C. Endocervical polyp
  • • Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.
  • • Option D. Subserosal fibroid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Death rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Relative risk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR) Strength of association: Relative risk (cohort study) Odds ratio (case control study)

  • ➤ Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • ➤ Strength of association: Relative risk (cohort study) Odds ratio (case control study)
  • ➤ Relative risk (cohort study) Odds ratio (case control study)
  • ➤ Relative risk (cohort study)
  • ➤ Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.
  • ➤ Endo-myocardial biopsy
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a resource-limited setting presents to a local health camp with complaints of chronic eye irritation and a gritty feeling in her eyes for the past few months. On examination, conjunctival scarring and inward turning of the eyelashes are noted. The physician suspects trachoma and recalls the recommended WHO's SAFE strategy for managing trachoma in endemic areas. What does the "S" in the SAFE strategy stand for in this context? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "S" in the WHO's SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Trachoma Treatment
  • ➤ Trachoma Treatment
  • ➤ Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20 mg/kg oral stat Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma: District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma) District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO] Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days

  • ➤ District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
  • ➤ District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
  • ➤ District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary
  • ➤ Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO] Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days
  • ➤ Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO]
  • ➤ Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days

  • ➤ India declared ‘Trachoma-Free’ in December 2017.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? ( INICET Nov 2021) ESV: End-systolic volume EDV: End-diastolic volume

options.label: A
options.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope

options.label: B
options.text: Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

options.label: C
options.text: End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope

options.label: D
options.text: Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.correct_answer: B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contraindications to gastric lavage:
  • ➤ Contraindications to gastric lavage:
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation ( exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely). Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients , Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene) U pper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices Hypothermia Hemorrhagic diathesis
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation ( exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons
  • ➤ exception carbolic acid
  • ➤ Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients , Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  • ➤ Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients
  • ➤ Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  • ➤ U pper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices

  • ➤ Hypothermia
  • ➤ Hypothermia
  • ➤ Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms? (INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fat embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.
  • ➤ History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.
  • ➤ History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.
  • ➤ two years.

questions.text: Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? ( INICET Nov 2022) 1. Median nerve 2. Radial nerve 3. Tendon of biceps brachi 4. Brachial artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:
  • • 1. Median nerve
  • • 2. Brachial artery
  • • 3. Tendon of biceps brachii
  • • 4. Radial nerve
  • • The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:
  • • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • • The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study

options.label: C
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

options.label: D
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with an ulcer on his neck, and a biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with negative lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local excision with frozen border

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide local excision with radiation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wide local excision with radiation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate management strategy for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck with negative lymph nodes is wide local excision to remove the tumor completely, often followed by radiotherapy to address any potential microscopic residual disease.

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chancroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with cough and congestion in the chest. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation (AF) and on examination, he had an irregularly irregular pulse and ECG showed AF with a heart rate of 52/min. His current medications are KCl 10 mEq BID, Triamterene, ASA 100mg/day, Atenolol 50 mg BID, and Clarithromycin. Two months ago, his digoxin levels were 1.5 ng/mL and currently, it rose to 3.4 ng/mL. Which of the following is responsible for such an increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clarithromycin, by inhibiting CYP3A4, can significantly elevate digoxin levels, leading to toxicity. When prescribing medications, it is essential to consider potential drug-drug interactions, especially with drugs like digoxin that have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dhatura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Albumin is a negative acute phase reactant that decreases during inflammation, while CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin are positive acute phase reactants that increase.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hoarding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT. Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes .
  • ➤ poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.
  • ➤ OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.
  • ➤ OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: Which drug induces the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Norepinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is the drug that induces the observed response of increased systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure along with reflex bradycardia. This is due to its potent alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction and initial beta-1 stimulation, followed by the baroreceptor reflex reducing heart rate. Other drugs like dopamine, epinephrine, and isoproterenol have different profiles of action and do not produce this specific combination of effects.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical scenario of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following results can be seen on Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Direct positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Van den Bergh reaction is a chemical reaction used to measure bilirubin levels in blood, specifically amount of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.
  • ➤ Principle: bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulphanilic acid to produce purple colored azobilirubin. This reaction is highly useful in understanding the nature of jaundice.
  • ➤ This test helps to identify the type of jaundice –
  • ➤ The serum of the patient is mixed with diazo reagent. If a red color develops immediately, it is called a direct positive . It happens if conjugated bilirubin is present. In an indirect positive test, the patient's serum is first treated with alcohol and later mixed with diazo reagent. This causes development of a red color. It is seen if unconjugated bilirubin is present. If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic reaction.
  • ➤ The serum of the patient is mixed with diazo reagent. If a red color develops immediately, it is called a direct positive . It happens if conjugated bilirubin is present.
  • ➤ direct positive
  • ➤ conjugated bilirubin
  • ➤ In an indirect positive test, the patient's serum is first treated with alcohol and later mixed with diazo reagent. This causes development of a red color. It is seen if unconjugated bilirubin is present.
  • ➤ indirect
  • ➤ unconjugated
  • ➤ If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic reaction.
  • ➤ If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Color blindness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Color blindness is an X-linked disorder, meaning that the gene causing the condition is located on the X chromosome, which primarily affects males and is passed down from carrier mothers.
